justification: The methods note that “participants aged 8 to 25 years completed a novel task that enabled us to measure their preferences for agentic choice across conditions in which the instrumental value of choice varied,” indicating the task served as the instrument for assessing agentic-choice preference.

In the questionnaire section the authors state, “All participants completed the Desirability of Control scale (Burger & Cooper, 1979),” showing this scale operationalised the Desirability-of-Control construct.
For adults, the paper reports that they “additionally completed the Locus of Control questionnaire (Nowicki & Duke, 1974),” linking this measure to the Locus-of-Control construct.

measured_by: Locus of Control scale for children (Nowicki & Strickland, 1973)
justification: The authors note that participants aged 10–17 “completed analogous child-friendly versions of the questionnaires: the Locus of Control (Nowicki & Strickland, 1973),” showing this child version measured the same construct.
The text lists that adults filled out “the State-Trait Anxiety Index (Spielberger, 1989),” indicating this inventory was used to assess State–Trait Anxiety.
For younger participants, the paper specifies they completed the “State-Trait Anxiety Inventory for Children (Spielberger & Edwards, 1973),” linking this child form to the anxiety construct.
Adults were given “Beck's Depression Inventory (Beck et al., 1996),” identifying the BDI as the measure of depressive symptoms.
Participants aged 10–17 completed “the Children Depression Inventory (Kovacs, 1992),” demonstrating this scale measured depression in the younger cohort.
